user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysconf_fallback_:
```c
static int
mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysconf_fallback_ (void)
{
  int ret = -1;
#if defined(HAVE_SYSCONF) && \
  (defined(HAS_DECL__SC_CRAY_NCPU) || defined(HAS_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF))
  long value = -1;
#ifdef HAS_DECL__SC_CRAY_NCPU
  if (0 >= value)
    value = sysconf (_SC_CRAY_NCPU);
#endif /* HAS_DECL__SC_CRAY_NCPU */
#ifdef HAS_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF
  if (0 >= value)
    value = sysconf (_SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF);
#endif /* HAS_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF */
  if (0 >= value)
    return -1;
  ret = (int) value;
  if ((long) ret != value)
    return -1; /* Overflow */
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCONF &&
          (HAS_DECL__SC_CRAY_NCPU || HAS_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF) */
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#ifdef HAS_DECL__SC_CRAY_NCPU
  if (0 >= value)
    value = sysconf (_SC_CRAY_NCPU);
#endif /* HAS_DECL__SC_CRAY_NCPU */
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The 'if (0 >= value)' guard is evaluated with value previously initialized to -1 in the same function, so the guarded statement (value = sysconf(_SC_CRAY_NCPU);) is reachable when the HAS_DECL__SC_CRAY_NCPU macro causes the block to be compiled. There is no unreachable statement or dead code in this fragment (the false branch does not exist), and the conditional is used to prevent subsequent sysconf calls when an earlier call has already produced a non‑negative result in other compilation configurations.
